para.para: Autogenerated identifier classes and identifier objects to Themed Icons registered with .
Identifier classes should be used in attributes, XAML, or generic parameters. Where an value is expected, use the identifier object in the Id field of the identifier class.

remarks.para: This code was compile-time generated to support Themed Icons in the JetBrains application.

It has two primary goals: load the icons of this assembly to be registered with so that they were WPF-accessible and theme-sensitive; and emit early-bound accessors for referencing icons in codebehind in a compile-time-validated manner.
For performance reasons, the icons are not individually exposed with application resources. There is a custom markup extension to bind an image source in markup.
To use an icon from XAML, set an property to the markup extension, which takes an icon identifier class (nested in class) as a parameter.
Example:
remarks.code: <Image Source="{icons:ThemedIcon myres:StructuralSearchServicesThemedIcons+EditPattern}" />
remarks.para: Sometimes you have to reference an icon from a type attriute when you're defining objects in code. Typical examples are Options pages and Tool Windows.

To avoid the use of string IDs which are not validated very well, we've emitted identifier classes to be used with typeof() expression, one per each icon. Use the attribute overload which takes a for an image, and choose your icon class from nested classes in the class.
Example:
remarks.code: [Item(Name="Sample", Icon=typeof(StructuralSearchServicesThemedIcons.EditPattern))]
remarks.para: In codebehind, we have two distinct tasks: (a) specify some icon in the APIs and (b) render icon images onscreen.

On the APIs stage you should only manipulate icon identifier objects (of type , statically defined in in Id fields). Icon identifier classes (nested in ) should be turned into icon identifier objects as early as possible. Rendering is about getting an to assign to WPF, or to use with GDI+ / Windows Forms.

You should turn an identifier object into a rendered image as late as possible. The identifier is static and lightweight and does not depend on the current theme, while the image is themed and has to be loaded or generated/rasterized. You need an instance to get the image out of an icon identifier object. Once you got the image, you should take care to change it with theme changes — either by using a live image property, or by listening to the theme change event. See and its extensions for the related facilities.
Example:
remarks.code: // Getting IconId identifier object to use with APIs IconId iconid = StructuralSearchServicesThemedIcons.EditPattern.Id;
// Getting IconId out of an Icon Identifier Class type IconId iconid = CompiledIconClassAttribute.TryGetCompiledIconClassId(typeof(StructuralSearchServicesThemedIcons.EditPattern), OnError.Throw);
// Getting image for screen rendering by IconId themediconmanager.Icons[icnoid]
// Getting image for screen rendering by Icon Identifier Class themediconmanager.GetIcon<StructuralSearchServicesThemedIcons.EditPattern>()
remarks.para: This code was generated by a pre-compile build task from a set of input files which are XAML files adhering to a certain convention, as convenient for exporting them from the Illustrator workspace, plus separate PNG files with raster icons. In the projects, these files are designated with ThemedIconsXamlV3 and ThemedIconPng build actions and do not themselves get into the output assembly. All of such files are processed, vector images for different themes of the same icon are split and combined into the single list of icons in this assembly. This list is then written into the genearted XAML file (compiled into BAML within assembly), and serves as the source for this generated code.

para.para: Autogenerated identifier class for the EditPattern Themed Icon.
Identifier classes should be used in attributes, XAML, or generic parameters. Where an value is expected, use the identifier object in the field of the identifier class.

remarks.para: For details on Themed Icons and their use, see Remarks on class.

member.summary: Represents macro function definition that can be used by Live Template's. Implementation of this interface should be marked with attribute to be automatically recognized by ReSharper.

summary.para: Placeholder value is inserted into the text on the very initial step of template expansion and is needed for proper template text reformatting when real values cannot be calculated yet.

More precisely, the following steps are performed:
placeholder values for all template fields are inserted into the text
the resulting text is reformatted
is used to evaluate and insert values for all fields.

member.name: F:JetBrains.ReSharper.Feature.Services.UI.CompletionPicker.CompletionPickerEditWpf.IsCompletionListVisible
member.summary: Gets whether we've ruled out that the completion list should be visible at the moment. This means is and the 's are not empty (and the model exists, in the first place).

member.name: F:JetBrains.ReSharper.Feature.Services.UI.CompletionPicker.CompletionPickerEditWpf.myEvtUpdateTextBeforeCaret
member.summary: As we can't (so it seems) get the event of caret movement in the edit box, we'd udpate it every so often. Probably the caret position can't change without a Windows message on the control, so we'd apply the change after each message, with a small delay needed just to group multiple consequent messages together. GEvent is better than BeginInvoke because the latter adds to the messages itself and cannot guarantee all fo the dependent messages go thru before it executes.

para.para: Autogenerated identifier classes and identifier objects to Themed Icons registered with .
Identifier classes should be used in attributes, XAML, or generic parameters. Where an value is expected, use the identifier object in the Id field of the identifier class.

remarks.para: This code was compile-time generated to support Themed Icons in the JetBrains application.

It has two primary goals: load the icons of this assembly to be registered with so that they were WPF-accessible and theme-sensitive; and emit early-bound accessors for referencing icons in codebehind in a compile-time-validated manner.
For performance reasons, the icons are not individually exposed with application resources. There is a custom markup extension to bind an image source in markup.
To use an icon from XAML, set an property to the markup extension, which takes an icon identifier class (nested in class) as a parameter.
Example:
remarks.code: <Image Source="{icons:ThemedIcon myres:AlteringFeatuThemedIcons+CodeCleanupOptionPage}" />
remarks.para: Sometimes you have to reference an icon from a type attriute when you're defining objects in code. Typical examples are Options pages and Tool Windows.

To avoid the use of string IDs which are not validated very well, we've emitted identifier classes to be used with typeof() expression, one per each icon. Use the attribute overload which takes a for an image, and choose your icon class from nested classes in the class.
Example:
remarks.code: [Item(Name="Sample", Icon=typeof(AlteringFeatuThemedIcons.CodeCleanupOptionPage))]
remarks.para: In codebehind, we have two distinct tasks: (a) specify some icon in the APIs and (b) render icon images onscreen.

On the APIs stage you should only manipulate icon identifier objects (of type , statically defined in in Id fields). Icon identifier classes (nested in ) should be turned into icon identifier objects as early as possible. Rendering is about getting an to assign to WPF, or to use with GDI+ / Windows Forms.

You should turn an identifier object into a rendered image as late as possible. The identifier is static and lightweight and does not depend on the current theme, while the image is themed and has to be loaded or generated/rasterized. You need an instance to get the image out of an icon identifier object. Once you got the image, you should take care to change it with theme changes — either by using a live image property, or by listening to the theme change event. See and its extensions for the related facilities.
Example:
remarks.code: // Getting IconId identifier object to use with APIs IconId iconid = AlteringFeatuThemedIcons.CodeCleanupOptionPage.Id;
// Getting IconId out of an Icon Identifier Class type IconId iconid = CompiledIconClassAttribute.TryGetCompiledIconClassId(typeof(AlteringFeatuThemedIcons.CodeCleanupOptionPage), OnError.Throw);
// Getting image for screen rendering by IconId themediconmanager.Icons[icnoid]
// Getting image for screen rendering by Icon Identifier Class themediconmanager.GetIcon<AlteringFeatuThemedIcons.CodeCleanupOptionPage>()
remarks.para: This code was generated by a pre-compile build task from a set of input files which are XAML files adhering to a certain convention, as convenient for exporting them from the Illustrator workspace, plus separate PNG files with raster icons. In the projects, these files are designated with ThemedIconsXamlV3 and ThemedIconPng build actions and do not themselves get into the output assembly. All of such files are processed, vector images for different themes of the same icon are split and combined into the single list of icons in this assembly. This list is then written into the genearted XAML file (compiled into BAML within assembly), and serves as the source for this generated code.

remarks.para: This code was compile-time generated to support Themed Icons in the JetBrains application.

It has two primary goals: load the icons of this assembly to be registered with so that they were WPF-accessible and theme-sensitive; and emit early-bound accessors for referencing icons in codebehind in a compile-time-validated manner.
For performance reasons, the icons are not individually exposed with application resources. There is a custom markup extension to bind an image source in markup.
To use an icon from XAML, set an property to the markup extension, which takes an icon identifier class (nested in class) as a parameter.
Example:
remarks.code: <Image Source="{icons:ThemedIcon myres:DaemonThemedIcons+Recursion}" />
remarks.para: Sometimes you have to reference an icon from a type attriute when you're defining objects in code. Typical examples are Options pages and Tool Windows.

To avoid the use of string IDs which are not validated very well, we've emitted identifier classes to be used with typeof() expression, one per each icon. Use the attribute overload which takes a for an image, and choose your icon class from nested classes in the class.
Example:
remarks.code: [Item(Name="Sample", Icon=typeof(DaemonThemedIcons.Recursion))]
remarks.para: In codebehind, we have two distinct tasks: (a) specify some icon in the APIs and (b) render icon images onscreen.

On the APIs stage you should only manipulate icon identifier objects (of type , statically defined in in Id fields). Icon identifier classes (nested in ) should be turned into icon identifier objects as early as possible. Rendering is about getting an to assign to WPF, or to use with GDI+ / Windows Forms.

You should turn an identifier object into a rendered image as late as possible. The identifier is static and lightweight and does not depend on the current theme, while the image is themed and has to be loaded or generated/rasterized. You need an instance to get the image out of an icon identifier object. Once you got the image, you should take care to change it with theme changes — either by using a live image property, or by listening to the theme change event. See and its extensions for the related facilities.
Example:
remarks.code: // Getting IconId identifier object to use with APIs IconId iconid = DaemonThemedIcons.Recursion.Id;
// Getting IconId out of an Icon Identifier Class type IconId iconid = CompiledIconClassAttribute.TryGetCompiledIconClassId(typeof(DaemonThemedIcons.Recursion), OnError.Throw);
// Getting image for screen rendering by IconId themediconmanager.Icons[icnoid]
// Getting image for screen rendering by Icon Identifier Class themediconmanager.GetIcon<DaemonThemedIcons.Recursion>()
remarks.para: This code was generated by a pre-compile build task from a set of input files which are XAML files adhering to a certain convention, as convenient for exporting them from the Illustrator workspace, plus separate PNG files with raster icons. In the projects, these files are designated with ThemedIconsXamlV3 and ThemedIconPng build actions and do not themselves get into the output assembly. All of such files are processed, vector images for different themes of the same icon are split and combined into the single list of icons in this assembly. This list is then written into the genearted XAML file (compiled into BAML within assembly), and serves as the source for this generated code.

remarks.para: This code was compile-time generated to support Themed Icons in the JetBrains application.

It has two primary goals: load the icons of this assembly to be registered with so that they were WPF-accessible and theme-sensitive; and emit early-bound accessors for referencing icons in codebehind in a compile-time-validated manner.
For performance reasons, the icons are not individually exposed with application resources. There is a custom markup extension to bind an image source in markup.
To use an icon from XAML, set an property to the markup extension, which takes an icon identifier class (nested in class) as a parameter.
Example:
remarks.code: <Image Source="{icons:ThemedIcon myres:PsiServicesThemedIcons+Collapse}" />
remarks.para: Sometimes you have to reference an icon from a type attriute when you're defining objects in code. Typical examples are Options pages and Tool Windows.

To avoid the use of string IDs which are not validated very well, we've emitted identifier classes to be used with typeof() expression, one per each icon. Use the attribute overload which takes a for an image, and choose your icon class from nested classes in the class.
Example:
remarks.code: [Item(Name="Sample", Icon=typeof(PsiServicesThemedIcons.Collapse))]
remarks.para: In codebehind, we have two distinct tasks: (a) specify some icon in the APIs and (b) render icon images onscreen.

On the APIs stage you should only manipulate icon identifier objects (of type , statically defined in in Id fields). Icon identifier classes (nested in ) should be turned into icon identifier objects as early as possible. Rendering is about getting an to assign to WPF, or to use with GDI+ / Windows Forms.

You should turn an identifier object into a rendered image as late as possible. The identifier is static and lightweight and does not depend on the current theme, while the image is themed and has to be loaded or generated/rasterized. You need an instance to get the image out of an icon identifier object. Once you got the image, you should take care to change it with theme changes — either by using a live image property, or by listening to the theme change event. See and its extensions for the related facilities.
Example:
remarks.code: // Getting IconId identifier object to use with APIs IconId iconid = PsiServicesThemedIcons.Collapse.Id;
// Getting IconId out of an Icon Identifier Class type IconId iconid = CompiledIconClassAttribute.TryGetCompiledIconClassId(typeof(PsiServicesThemedIcons.Collapse), OnError.Throw);
// Getting image for screen rendering by IconId themediconmanager.Icons[icnoid]
// Getting image for screen rendering by Icon Identifier Class themediconmanager.GetIcon<PsiServicesThemedIcons.Collapse>()
remarks.para: This code was generated by a pre-compile build task from a set of input files which are XAML files adhering to a certain convention, as convenient for exporting them from the Illustrator workspace, plus separate PNG files with raster icons. In the projects, these files are designated with ThemedIconsXamlV3 and ThemedIconPng build actions and do not themselves get into the output assembly. All of such files are processed, vector images for different themes of the same icon are split and combined into the single list of icons in this assembly. This list is then written into the genearted XAML file (compiled into BAML within assembly), and serves as the source for this generated code.

member.name: F:JetBrains.ReSharper.Feature.Services.UI.CompletionPicker.CompletionPickerEdit.myEvtUpdateTextBeforeCaret
member.summary: As we can't (so it seems) get the event of caret movement in the edit box, we'd udpate it every so often. Probably the caret position can't change without a Windows message on the control, so we'd apply the change after each message, with a small delay needed just to group multiple consequent messages together. GEvent is better than BeginInvoke because the latter adds to the messages itself and cannot guarantee all fo the dependent messages go thru before it executes.

member.name: T:JetBrains.ReSharper.Feature.Services.MatchingBrace.ISimpleMatchingBraceProvider
member.summary: Provides token-level information about matching braces
member.remarks:
must be implemented according to the following rules:
It is defined on brace pairs, result for open and close brace of the same pair is the same
If one brace pair is "greater" than another that means that balance of "lesser" brace pair outside of "greater" brace pair doesn't count inside the "greater" brace pair
